Fields.DialogueText: Southampton? Southampton!
Down here, Captain!
Just getting my things in order.

Fields.MenuText: What things? Where are you planning on going?
There you are. I shouldn't have to look for my own ship.
Well, hurry up. We're embarking for Rotterdam before sundown.

Fields.DialogueText: Not far. Look what I found!
Well, look no further! I've found exactly what I need.
Exactly why I had to find one of... these!
You left to find a rock?
Not just any rock! See how flat it is? Perfect for skipping!
... Oi! What's so funny?
Easy there. I just don't think of a light cruiser skipping rocks!
Well, you can start today, Captain! I collect these from every port.
Any particular reason?
Personal fancy, really. I'm not sewing all the time, you know!
Could have fooled me.
Hmph. I'll have you know it's the most important domestic skill to learn! If you can't cook and you can't repair your clothing, you're a bit hopeless, aren't you?
Only your clothing?
Well, not only. The crew's been quite happy to come to me about fixing theirs.
So I've noticed. I've been meaning to talk to you about it, actually...
It'll have to wait, Captain. Looks as if those Morganas from earlier today want another go.
I'll get the crew to action stations, then. We'll table this, but only for now.
Of course! No use talking these things out unless it's over tea.
... Well, that too.
@BATTLE
I appreciate the tea, Southampton.
I'm glad! Picked up a little blackcurrant in Stavanger. I just couldn't keep it to myself!
Mmm. Funny you should mention that.
Why's that?
Three of the crew have approached me recently. They've reported some... interference with their wardrobe.
Oh, yes, I've been in and out of the crew's quarters. Strictly fleet business, mind you, I wouldn't be up to anything funny. Fixing up holes in the underclothes and all that.
Holes in the...? How can you possibly—
I can just tell, Captain. Nobody likes their pants falling apart, understand. You can see it in one's face every time!
Well, regardless, that's not what we're here to discuss.
Oh, bother, were they not satisfied with the improvements?
No, I'm afraid they... wait. "Improvements?"
A splash of colour here, a pocket there. I believe in form and function, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: I believe in keeping the uniforms uniform.
You don't think the uniforms are sufficient.
Let Command be the judge of what's functional.

Fields.DialogueText: Then you'll agree with me on this project I have in mind.
They're sufficient, but sufficient isn't good enough.
They can judge all they like, but there's always room for an appeal.
"Sufficient" is the best we've got. Most of our sailors are wearing patched-together uniforms from their countries of origin and the rest are wearing whatever we can procure in bulk.
That's the problem, Captain. In the long run we're going to need a single uniform for the Fleet, no matter a sailor's origin. Dress for teamwork and excellence or not at all!
It will most certainly not come to that.
So I do have permission to tinker with the uniforms?
Very funny.
Captain, I'm feeling some Morganas about to try their luck. We'll pick this up later. I think we've made brilliant progress today!
Every way I turn...
@BATTLE
The Neutrality Fleet is a work in progress. It is what it is.
Well, that's Norway behind us.
I'll miss it. All the fjords... you just don't get scenery like that where I'm from.
And Dover's next. That isn't too far from your hometown.
You're thinking of my namesake. I was laid down in Clydebank, Scotland. But Southampton may as well be my home.
We'll be defending it this week. In light of recent Morgana activity in Quiberon Bay, Command's deemed the Channel its top priority in Europe.
Quite the responsibility, isn't it?
Second only to the Suez and Panama Canals.
It'd be a tragedy to lose those. They might be my favorite thing about you humans.
What do you mean?
Once upon a time I would have had to go all the way around a continent to get to the other side. Now I can just sail from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea and to India, easy as you please!
Distance has always been our greatest enemy. The easier it is to travel and communicate, the better for mankind.
And if the land's in your way, you just carve straight through! Simply amazing...

Fields.MenuText: The canals are even better in person.
We wouldn't let a little thing like a continent get in our way.
If it brings us closer together, there's nothing we won't do.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe one day. We certainly get enough excitement here in home waters lately.
Certainly not! The Morganas don't know what they're getting into.
That gives me hope, Captain. You're a cooperative lot.
Well, look lively. We've been tracking Murder, and it looks like she's making a run of the Channel. Action stations.
Don't need to tell me twice!
@BATTLE
Isn't the Channel grand, Captain? You can see France from here!
England's oldest neighbour.
Are we due to visit during the tour?
As it happens, we're scheduled to dock in Calais briefly.
It's so exciting! I've never been to France before.
No?
There was an ancestor of mine who came close. Ever read about the Grace Dieu?
Not another French ship?
Sounds like it, but no. Henry V had her built way back in the 1400s for home defence.
What happened to her?
Well, not a whole lot. She only had one voyage and spent the rest of her time at home. Not even built very well, either.
That's it?
Sadly. She was finally struck by lightning and burned down.

Fields.MenuText: That's a disappointment.
Well, English ships have come pretty far since then.
No danger of that with you, at least.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't need to tell me twice. But it was the start of a long and glorious history of Sotonian shipbuilding!
We have, haven't we? Not to brag or anything...
Steel doesn't burn, Captain!
Could have been worse, though. Sweden built a huge warship that sank a mile into its first voyage!
The Vasa. I did read about that! All of Europe's elite were watching when she just tipped over.
Ooh, that seaplane cruiser Gotland hates it when I tell that story.
Calamity is within firing range. Let's Vasa her, shall we?
Ha! I'm keeping that next time I visit Sweden.
@BATTLE
Welcome to Calais!
Mmmm... there's something relaxing about a fresh port. Reminds one of home, no?
The smell of a home-cooked meal, the feeling of land under one's feet...
A good refuel and reload, perhaps an engine refitting...
I think port means something different to you than it does to me.
Well, I can't go on land, can I?
You didn't seem to have an issue with it in Stavanger or Dover.
When we're close enough to the coast. Much further than ten metres or so, and you know I stop right in my tracks!
Oh, that reminds me! Hold on, back in a tick...
There she goes. Who knew ships could have rock collections...
Found one! And not a moment too soon! Action stations!
Right you are, Southampton! Oh, about the rocks...
Later, Captain! These are going to be right menaces, I can sense it!
@BATTLE
I never took you for a geologist, Southampton.
Oh, the rocks? Couldn't tell you what kind they are! But even a homebody like me loves a unique memento from an exotic place.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't necessarily call France "exotic."
Rocks aren't that unique.
I thought you skipped the rocks?

Fields.DialogueText: Anywhere's exotic if you can only see the coast.
It's not the rock, really... it's what the rock represents.
Not at first. I wait until another port to do that... another sea.
It's an interesting hobby for a Belle to have.
No different than a human collecting seashells, is it? It's a piece of somewhere you don't belong.
Somewhere you'd like to see again.
Once this is all over... yes, definitely.
And we're moving!
You've heard the news?
Only that our convoy's set to tour the Mediterranean! Isn't it exciting, Captain?
It's a beautiful sea. Dangerous these days, too.
Oh, where isn't it dangerous?
Nothing like a war for broadening the horizons.
Too true, too true. A bit ironic, isn't it? To see all sorts of new places, but only when they might be destroyed at any moment?

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure that's irony?
That's a rather morbid way of looking at it.
Another reason to collect rocks?

Fields.DialogueText: Fairly certain. I'm not really the literary type.
Oh, I don't know. Every battle is an opportunity, isn't it? We're making it safe for beautiful places to be beautiful.
Sort of. I'm not really certain how to explain it, to tell you the truth...
But no matter where you are, it's tea time somewhere. Earl Grey?
Perhaps another time. No doubt the Morganas have caught wind of our intended route.
Action stations, then?
Well, I wanted to ask you... oh, never mind. Perhaps after the battle.
Oh, don't tease me, Captain! I can't concentrate when I'm curious...
@BATTLE
Is that a uniform in your hands?
It will be. Call it a work in progress, Captain.
I thought I told you no experimenting on the crew.
Oh, it's no experiment! Everyone knows it's hot in the Mediterranean. The crew'll need shorter sleeves or they just won't be comfortable.

Fields.MenuText: Nobody joins their navy expecting comfort.
Yes, but on the dress uniforms?
I'm sure the will crew appreciate it, but will Command?

Fields.DialogueText: That's why it'll be a pleasant surprise!
Especially on the dress uniforms. I won't have anyone passing out during a ceremony!
If they don't, I'm sure they'll come around. It's a new world, a new war... anything could happen. They should encourage innovation!
I know your heart's in the right place. I just don't want to see you get in trouble.
I appreciate your concern, really I do, but it's all right. We all keep the world safe in our own way. For me, that means making sure my crew are well fed and clothed.
I certainly can't complain. You already do an excellent job of protecting them.
And of protecting you, Captain?
... Yes, I suppose you do. I'm as much a part of the crew as any of our sailors.
You just happen to be the one in charge.
Primus inter pares, I like to think.
What's that mean? Sounds fancy.
Anything but, actually. Primus inter pares means "first among equals."
Hmm. I like it. We've all got our responsibilities, after all...
*ALARM*
I do want to see your dress uniform designs. Mind getting me a few sketches?
Once the dust settles. Can't very well draw with gunfire shaking my hull!
@BATTLE
Besides, the crew have been sweating like madmen. One of them practically threw this uniform at me when I mentioned I was doing some tailoring.
I suppose you're still thinking about those new designs as well.
I've been hoping you would. It takes all kinds, Captain, but out here the crew need to see they're in this together, always. Especially with the madness going on on land.
That's what a uniform does. Besides, think of how much easier maintenance will be with a universal design for the fleet!
I was going to work on the dress uniforms first so as not to rock the boat too terribly, but I thought this would be more important.
I'm afraid there are admirals out there that would see Belles devising their own uniforms as the first step toward Belles forming their own Praetorian Guards.
Dear me... humid today, isn't it?
We're indoors. How can you tell?
Corrosion, mostly. The sea air can really play hell with steel...

Fields.MenuText: I... can't really relate to that.
Sort of like sweating?
How does a Belle handle it?

Fields.DialogueText: Think of it like... a sunburn, perhaps? Except that goes away on its own, doesn't it?
A bit. Perhaps more like a sunburn? I've seen some Belles look a little rusty after a few months at sea...
She stands up straight and takes it like a ship of the line! We have humans for the rest.
I suppose there isn't much we can do about it right now.
Save for throwing some ice in our tea, probably not. On a cooler note, I've finished the Mediterranean uniforms!
When do the crew get to wear them?
A fantastic question! If you'll look out the porthole...
... Southampton, are they playing football?
The helmsman suggested it, Captain! Cotton breathes well, but I had to test it against heavy sweating just to be sure. What better way than with a bit of sport?
I suppose you're right, but could you run this sort of thing by me next time?
Absolutely! We wouldn't want to leave you out of the game, would we?
That's not... well, never mind.
I'll just put you down for the tournament on... blast! Here they come now. See them?
Looks like the game's on hold for the day.
@BATTLE
One of these days, I'm going to get you to change up how you take your tea.
Not any time soon. I like my tea how it is.
Well, I am glad you appreciate the taste. Tea is a fickle animal. Strong for one person means oversteeped for another.
We were discussing Calamity, I think. One of those Morganas.
Ugh, yes. Awful name, that. Ships' names are supposed to be inspiring!
All the Morganas are that way. Despair, Corruption, Paranoia...  I just don't see why.
Because they're evil, of course. Although... hmm.
Go on.
Well, you humans christened us Belles. What I wonder is where the Morganas got their names.
And why they're named in languages we can understand?
Exactly! They had to come from somewhere, didn't they?
Well, where did you come from?
You know, I never really thought about it. You built me, and then I just... was. So the Morganas had to have been built, no?

Fields.MenuText: But who built them?
Well, that just means they can be unbuilt.
Can we talk about something else?

Fields.DialogueText: They certainly aren't telling.
Like taking apart a sweater to learn the pattern.
Well, one can't help but wonder...
Wherever they came from, it's from somewhere or someone that understands you humans.
Someone who hates us, maybe.
I don't understand. There's so much to love about you.
About humans?
... Yes. Exactly.
Tell Destruction that. We're drawing within range.
Perhaps I shall.
@BATTLE
We're coming up on Gibraltar. Any communication from Spain?
None. Franco only speaks to Command. And Command tells me we're all right as long as we don't "violate Spanish sovereignty."
What's that mean?
Whatever the Falangists want it to mean, I suspect. Until we get to Gibraltar, we're treading very carefully.
Hmm...
Something on your mind?
No, it's not important.

Fields.MenuText: If you say so.
Try me.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, maybe it's a little important.
You're going to laugh.
It's just...
What?
Does a rock from Gibraltar count as Spanish or British?
We're in the middle of a war, Southampton!
What's a war but a question of what belongs where?
I guess I can't argue with that. It would probably be... a little of both?
It's certainly the furthest I've been from home. I'm keeping a bit of the Rock when we leave.
One of these days, you'll have to tell me more about this hobby of yours.
One of these days. Do you find that rocks skip differently on different seas?
I really couldn't tell you.
Well, wherever we are, Morganas all burn the same. We've got a couple here in the Gulf of Cadiz waiting to prove that.
Vigilant as always.
@BATTLE
Ah... home away from home!
As long as Spain maintains their neutrality.
I wouldn't worry, Captain.
You're that sure that Franco can be trusted?
Not at all. But there's no sense losing sleep over it. Let Madrid and London figure these things out.
You're not wrong. As Captain I have to dwell on these things a little.
True. That's what we have tea for, isn't it?
Maybe. Though the crew have been uneasy as well. Fascist Spain to the north, Morganas to the south...
And an international crew made up of sailors whose countries just went to war. I see what you mean, Captain.
It takes more than tea to work some things out.
More than tea... or more tea!

Fields.MenuText: I don't think you're listening to me.
What do you mean?
You mean for the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: Just hear me out. What's worked for us can work for our men, can't it?
I mean that maybe what works for us can work for the men. A spot of tea now and then calms the mind right up.
Got it in one!
Look at us. We've always done well with a pot of tea after a trying day. Who's to say the crew won't as well?
That's a tall order, Southampton. Do you have any idea how much tea we'll need for the entire crew?
There's two of us, so simple maths should get us an answer. Not to mention the sandwiches, the desserts, perhaps some ale...
One thing at a time, Southampton. If you think this will be good for the crew, fine, but the mission comes first. We're here to supply British Mediterranean possessions.
Which includes Royal Navy ships here in the Mediterranean, no?
You know that's not what I mean.
Worth a shot... and so are the Morganas. Action stations!
Always on task, at least...
@BATTLE
Where's our next destination, then?
Eager to get out of Gibraltar?
The opposite, really. I'm still wrapping my mind around how... homely it feels.
It's been a British possession for centuries.
I know, but it's still so strange. It's like... have you ever visited a friend and they've had the same furniture as you? Or the same pictures on their walls?
I suppose so.
Their home is different... but the same. That's what Gibraltar is to me. It's nice to see foreign places, but to find a little bit of home overseas... well, it's a pleasant surprise.
I'm glad you feel that way. We're on a tour of the British Mediterranean, after all. Malta's our next stop, then Cyprus, and then Alexandria.
Egypt!
Correct. Egypt has reported heavy Morgana activity on both sides of the Suez Canal, and we're the relief force.
We don't have any time to waste, do we? If the Morganas seize the canal, we're cut off from half the world!

Fields.MenuText: Malta is a central British base in these waters. Barring an emergency, we're headed there first.
I'll see to it that we get there as soon as possible.
India can take care of itself.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you're right. Still, there's more to the war than just home waters...
I hope you do, Captain. There's so much more we have to protect than ourselves.
Maybe it can, but it shouldn't have to! Our colonies, our responsibility.
Command calls the shots in the end. Are we ready to leave?
Just give me the word, Captain. By the look of it, those Morganas won't wait.
Time to break into the Mediterranean.
@BATTLE
Have you had a chance to look over the requisitions for the tea?
Yes, and I have to say, they're a little ambitious.
Ambitious, but not impossible. The French ports should be a little friendlier than the Spanish, no?
It's not really a question of whether we can get the supplies. We can. I just don't know how I can sell a tea party to Command.
Why, as a team-building exercise! I've been busy working up new dress uniforms for the crew—you can pass my designs along to Command with your next requisition. Show them we're serious.

Fields.MenuText: Do you have them with you?
Southampton, we haven't the time for playing dress-up.
I'd almost forgotten about those. Can I see them?

Fields.DialogueText: Right here, Captain. If you'll look at the sleeves in particular...
Please, Captain? I've spoken to the crew and they're all on board... they seem quite glad to be all on a little more equal footing.
Absolutely! I think I've ironed out all the issues, so to speak. Questions? Comments?
Let's see...
Honour cords on the sleeves, new medal designs... what's this on the shoulders?
Big old C83, Captain! My pennant number in gold thread. I know you said no epaulettes, so I figured some fancy shoulder pads couldn't hurt.
Honestly, I like it. Different crews could have their respective ships' numbers. I'm sure the other Belles would appreciate that.
And it reminds the crew who's watching over them. I can't be everywhere at once, but I can come close.
You've put a lot of thought into this. Look, I'll put a good word in with Command. As far as food goes, I'll see what I can get in each port on the tour. No promises, but I'll try.
That'll mean a lot to the crew, so it means a lot to me. Thank you, Captain!... Bugger, there's a Morgana right ahead. They pick the worst times, don't they?
They do at that. We're moving to engage. And Southampton?
Yes?
What you said about watching over the crew... is there space for my name on those shoulder pads?
Left room just in case.
@BATTLE
Damn. Southampton, we're making a detour.
Oh, dear. What's the problem?
Our spotter planes are reporting heavy Morgana activity in the Sea of Sardinia... what we can see through the clouds, anyway. It's not a maelstrom, but it's big.
We're to avoid it, then. Well, that's frustrating! Puts us right out of our way.
That it does. We'll be taking the long way around. Our next stop is Monaco. Prince Louis has already agreed—
Monaco, is it?
Southampton, you're spilling your tea.
Never mind what I'm doing with my bloody tea. You couldn't pay me to come within fifty miles of that thieving rock!
What in the world are you talking about?
Picture it. 1338. The poor city of Southampton is sacked, razed, plundered by forces from the Continent! And the spoils go right into the pocket of one Carlo Grimaldi, Lord of Monaco!
Are you serious?
As a rat infestation!
Southampton, that was six hundred years ago!
Care to calculate six centuries of interest on stolen treasure? I bloody don't! The Monegasque are still laughing their way to the bank! At me!

Fields.MenuText: Don't be ridiculous. We're stopping in Monaco, and that's that.
Is this really that sensitive of a subject for you?
Fine. We don't have to stop there, but you don't have to stock up for your tea party.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. You're the captain, after all.
We Belles have long memories, Captain. Southampton was in no fit state for an attack.
Captain... you wouldn't!
Monaco is neutral, wealthy, and safe. Port Hercules is our best option while the French ports are busy. Just cooperate and I'll see about getting your supplies while we're docked.
Just this once?
Think of it as taking back what's yours.
I think I can live with that, Captain. I suppose this means we're defending them from the nearby Morganas.
Tragically, yes.
Well, we'd better get moving. Wouldn't want them to burn it all down before I get the chance!
Whatever keeps you motivated.
@BATTLE
Bloody glad to be leaving today.
Let it go.
How to put this, Captain... haven't you ever had something taken from you?

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if the crew felt that way about their uniforms at first.
Not six centuries ago. I think Southampton's doing just fine these days.
Hasn't everyone?

Fields.DialogueText: Grr... that's different! I'm returning them new and improved!
Well, we didn't need thievery to do it!
Not everyone's had their city burned down!
War is hard on everyone, Southampton. Nobody goes into one thinking they're in the wrong. That's one of two things every belligerent has in common.
And the other?
Everyone wants it to end.
And yet here we are.
Well, we just disagree on how these things should end.
The crew can certainly attest to that.
Oh, that reminds me...
What's this, then?
Call it a shopping list. This is everything I was able to get from Port Hercules.
Captain... I could throw three teas for the crew with this! And this fabric... it'll keep me sewing for the whole tour!
The Prince is apparently quite taken with the Belles. He's one of Command's largest private benefactors. And speaking of charity... here.
Thank you! Thank you so much! You won't regret it!
I'm looking forward to seeing what you come up with... and so are a lot of other people.
... This still doesn't change how I feel about Monaco, you know.
It doesn't have to.
Oh, you know, that reminds me... how close are we to shore?
Close enough for you to pick up a rock or two?
How'd you guess?
Luck. But be quick about it, we're about to have some visitors.
Don't need to tell me twice! When I'm through with the Morganas, this city will be even deeper in debt to me!
I suppose that's a start.
@BATTLE
Eeeeee! One of my designs! When did he have the time to have it done!? I mean, the only way he could have known is if...
I might have shown him one or two of your dress uniform designs. He's got a thing for epaulettes, as it happens.
Reading over the Prince's manifest?
It's wonderful, Captain... and such a lot to take in. The Prince really raided his larder for us—there are teas here I've never even heard of before!
A little bit of flavor from around the world. You wanted the crew to get to know each other more. What better way than with an international menu?
Couldn't have put it better myself! And—my, there's a lot of dessert, isn't there?

Fields.MenuText: Enough for most of the convoy to attend, if they wish.
You'll barely need to cook. I hope the Prince hasn't upstaged you.
I don't think ships need to watch what they eat.

Fields.DialogueText: I can taste the strawberries now... oh! Decorations, too?
He can have the whole bloody theatre as long as the crew gets their tea!
Captain, you are lucky you can command me not to throw you overboard.
Floral arrangements are included, as well.
Yes, I noticed, the... oh. Oh...
Something wrong?
Yellow acacia and globe amaranth?
Do they clash?
No, they're actually quite lovely together, but... well, never mind.
No, tell me.
I'd prefer not to.
They're flowers. What's the harm?
No.
Southampton—
Good heavens, is that Disease? And headed straight for us, too! Action stations, Captain!
What's she on about?
@BATTLE
Rereading. And I keep getting distracted by these uniforms... you didn't have to do that, you know.
I wanted to. And you wanted to be seen. He's going to have a lot to talk about in his next letter to Command. He's heard a certain light cruiser's one hell of a seamstress.
What's all this laid out for?
Rehearsal, Captain. I thought you and I could sit down for a cuppa before we finalized the seating arrangements and such. Get a feel for what the crew's up for.
Right now?
If you're not busy.
No, not at all. What's on your mind?
I've been thinking a lot, Captain. About the war, about the Morganas. What would have happened with your war if none of this were going on?
If the Morganas hadn't appeared?
And if we hadn't appeared. If we were just... ships. Scone?
Thank you. It probably wouldn't have been such smooth sailing through the Ligurian Sea, I can tell you that.
It certainly is nice to only have one front to worry about.
Apart from that, it's anyone's guess. Anything between the Reich and the Soviets is at risk, and the French are digging in for another long haul. If the seas weren't neutral, I doubt we'd be here.
It's odd. I know why Britain's in this war. But I don't understand it.
What's not to understand?
Well, it's different with Belles, isn't it? We're here to fight the Morganas. One or the other of us wins, and then it's over.
What are you getting at?
You humans only have each other to fight. And as long as you remain, there will be wars. You will never reach a point at which wars will permanently cease.
I suppose that's likely. But that doesn't mean we fight wars for no reason.
So you condone these endless human wars?
I think fighting should be our last resort. But I wouldn't be the captain of a warship if I thought war was unnecessary.
I have to hope that there's a point to the wars we fight. That the world will be better off for these wars being fought. Certainly, I believe that to be the case as far as the Morganas are concerned.
I agree with you there, Captain. I appreciate your insight.
*ALARM*
It'll have to wait. Shall we?
@BATTLE
Oh, but enough depressing talk. There's an ensign who's just perfect for modeling that dress uniform over the tea. I've been dying to show you...
Captain, look out your porthole! You can see Malta on the horizon!
The nurse of the Mediterranean. We won't be staying long—just long enough to resupply for Alexandria.
Long enough to get the tea and the fashion show in order?

Fields.MenuText: Naturally. No sense entering contested waters on an empty stomach.
That's your business, not mine.
We've got a lot of materiel to handle. Don't get in anyone's way.

Fields.DialogueText: No sense wasting all this planning, after all!
Right you are, Captain. I'll keep festivities to the fore.
It's an open-air tea and runway, Captain. Might be difficult.
Right you are. We'll be relieved by the Cyprus fleet at the end of our stay.
Good. Can't let the island go a minute without a patrol. It's all that's keeping Alexandria alive.
Between the Morganas and the human war... they've got their work cut out for them.
We'll be a welcome sight. And spiffy, too, once I've finished the officers' uniforms!
You've been keeping them under lock and key. When can I wear mine?
One step ahead, Captain! It's hanging right there in your wardrobe right now, all pressed and ready to go. Take a look!
Southampton, this is a handsome piece of work! When did you finish it?
Just yesterday! Consider the other uniforms the prototypes. I figured out the perfect uniform for you once I'd mastered them.
Whoa. A little denser than it looks, isn't it?
Feel the chest area. There's armor plating between the layers.
Can't be too careful, I suppose.
Never!... Oh, speaking of, do you hear that?
Malta's either under attack or doing live fire drills. I've got a good idea of which.
Those Morganas certainly know how to pick their targets. Best get that uniform on, then.
Head to the bridge. I'll meet you there.
... Oh! Yes, of course.
@BATTLE
Yes, who is it?
This is your captain. Are you ready?
Oh, do come in!
Southampton, I—
You don't mind, do you? I just can't seem to attach this corsage...

Fields.MenuText: Not at all. Hold still.
You haven't asked one of the crew?
Er... that is... I—

Fields.DialogueText: Right! I've marked exactly where it's to be pinned.
I thought this required a more... official touch.
Oh, just take it, I won't bite!
I appreciate it, Captain. You'd think I'd be better with this sort of thing.
This is quite the corsage. What kind of flower is it?
Purple columbine! The Prince's floral arrangements gave me the idea.
You wear a lot of red and blue. It suits you.
Not only that, but there's a language to flowers, did you know that? They all mean different things!
So this one is—
Determination to win. The big event might be upon me, but I'm not dropping my guard one bit. It's for morale as much as marmalade.
And those Chinese chrysanthemums hung around the bridge?
Happiness under adversity!
What about those ones on the tea tables? The acacia and amaranth or whatever they were?
Ah... perhaps another time, Captain. I didn't pick them, I swear!
Southampton, what could they possibly—
Quiet! HMS St. Angelo's raised the alarm!
What about the tea things?
Grr... leave them! Leave them all. We'll be the only ones taking tea today!
She can't avoid this forever...
@BATTLE
Well, I'd call that tea a smashing success!
The crew certainly enjoyed it. Delays notwithstanding.
I think the gunsmoke added a certain zest to the atmosphere. Am I alone in that?
I don't think humans can appreciate it the same way a Belle might.
Fair. It's just another seasoning to me.
And the music! Did you know the helmsman could play the violin?
It was a pleasant surprise. I didn't know you could dance.
I didn't know half the crew could! And with each other, with no regard to their nations. Didn't I tell you this is exactly what they needed?
I'm impressed, Southampton. The crew ate like kings and had more fun than I've seen them have in a while. And that applause when your designs were modeled... you outdid yourself.
Just a matter of trust, Captain, and the party was excellent proof of concept. Anyone you can follow in a foxtrot you can follow in a battle!

Fields.MenuText: I'm still wondering about those flowers.
I wouldn't mind another dance, to tell you the truth.
What do we have left over? I've been meaning to take tea with you more often.

Fields.DialogueText: Proprietary information, Captain. Maybe if you get into event planning I'll let you know.
Right here? Right now? Well, we haven't any music, but I'm sure we can keep time somehow...
Watch what we eat and it'll last us through the rest of the tour!
Even the Morganas have been quiet today. I wonder why...
There's a reason for that.
There's what?
I received word during dessert. Alexandria's under siege. Command has ordered us there immediately to relieve the canal.
Under siege? What about Cyprus?
They'll just have to make do. Lose the Canal and we lose the Indian Ocean.
Whatever does the most good for the most people. When do we leave?
Tonight. I've already informed the crew.
*ALARM*
And the Morganas, apparently.
No, they just happened to overhear.
@BATTLE
It ought to do wonders for morale.
I'm so glad they feel the way I do, Captain. I think what they really needed was a sense of pride in the fleet and in themselves. The uniforms will remind them of that every day.
Benghazi wasn't terribly welcoming, was it?
Less so than Fort St. Angelo. Alexandria's next.
No rest for Command, is there?
None. The Morganas keep us all on our toes.
I wish you'd told me about the siege earlier, Captain.
You'd put so much into the tea for so long, and the uniforms are going to help the whole fleet. I didn't want to take that moment from you.
You've said it before—we're in the middle of a war. I may enjoy some housewarming now and again, but I'm still a soldier.
I should have treated you as such.
You've believed in my project from the beginning, and I appreciate you. But I need to be able to do what's right when it needs doing. Promise me you'll give me that.

Fields.MenuText: Whatever's necessary. You've got nothing but my trust.
As long as there's another tea in the cards.
Just be careful out there.

Fields.DialogueText: Same to you, Captain. That and a damn fine uniform.
Let's stick to the present for now.
I should say the same of you.
Are you ready?
Loaded for bear and itching for a scrap.
And your rocks?
Couple from St. Angelo, couple from Benghazi. You're catching on.
Curiosity. Between the rocks and the flowers, I wouldn't be surprised if you were planting your own garden behind my back.
Proprietary information, Captain. Maybe you'll have clearance after the Suez reopens for business.
A little incentive never hurt anyone.
We're approaching firing range. I think some holes in hulls are incentive enough, no?
Don't need to tell me twice.
@BATTLE
We're breaking off from the formation now.
It's to be a feint, then?
Correct. Our group engages and falls back, the Morganas pursue, and the destroyer group sweeps in for a flank.
Assuming the Morganas do what's expected of them.
At least some should. Compared to their strength, the most recent reports indicate more than enough of us for an encirclement.
How recent?
Last week. The clouds over the mouth of the Nile have been too thick to see anything since then.
What about radio?
The lines are down. That was the first thing to go.
Blast. They're getting smarter. Meanwhile, we're acting on week-old intelligence.

Fields.MenuText: I don't like it any more than you do, but we'll have to be ready for anything.
There's still time to fall back and request reinforcements from Cyprus.
Is this still something you're comfortable doing?

Fields.DialogueText: I've been tinkering with my armour for precisely that reason. We can take more than a few surprise rounds.
Never. Alexandria needs us. We've come this far—a little further won't kill us.
Whether it is or not, we're making a go of it. It's now or never.
This is what we signed up for, after all. Got to tone down the excitement in Alexandria, haven't we?
And in Port Said, and probably up and down the Nile for the next few days. It's going to be a rough one.
I do not say they cannot come. I only say that they cannot come by sea.
I thought you weren't the literary type.
Admiral John Jervis about Napoleon's navy. It's not literature—it's history. And that has a way of repeating itself. Let's Trafalgar those Morganas!
@BATTLE
I don't like this, Captain. The bay's been cleared, but the cloud cover's as thick as ever.
We're finally back in contact with Command, and it's not quite over yet.
You don't mean they're in the canal?
That's exactly what I mean. Settlements along the whole isthmus have been coming under fire.
That's sickening! There's nothing but nomads and farmers in that part of the country!
The Morganas don't care. Protect the military targets and they'll switch to the civilians.
Although... Captain, this might actually make things even easier.
It certainly might. The Morganas' keels are too deep to enter the Nile...
Meaning the only direction for them to go in is south.
But there's no fighting them in the canal. We don't have room to maneuver.
Not until we get to the Great Bitter Lake.

Fields.MenuText: You're suggesting we fight them there? You can't be serious.
Then that's where we'll take them down.
It's too convenient for them. We'd be walking right into a trap.

Fields.DialogueText: That's not what I'm suggesting at all. They're walking us right into a trap.
Captain, no! The shore's population is too high to risk another Fair Isle!
You're right. But I don't think there's anything else for it.
Damn it! The siege of Alexandria was nothing but a ruse. They wanted to draw us into the lake, where they're lying in wait.
So we spring the trap.
Southampton—
Captain, there's no other way. If we break off the chase now, they'll just come back up for another round. We need to scourge them from the canal. From the Red Sea, if necessary.
I suppose this is where you volunteer to lead the charge.
You read my mind, Captain. Next thing you know, we'll be finishing each other's—
Cute. When the shooting starts—
Be careful?
I was going to tell you to stand between the shells and our destroyers. But that too.
That's what the armour's for. Let's put it to use.
@BATTLE
Damn! It's exactly as I feared. The Morganas have cut off the lake's southern exit.
No escaping north... no escaping south... and we're in the middle.
And the cloud cover makes high-altitude bombers a liability. Friendly fire would be a real risk.
It's just us now... and we're surrounded. Do you know what this means, Captain?
Yes. We're going to have to break out and—
No, it means they can't escape us now!

Fields.MenuText: That's preposterous. We're going to be cut down where we stand!
I don't know whether you're loyal or crazy.
It's a long shot, but it's not impossible.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we'd better sink before my big sisters do!
Command can decide for themselves after we're done here.
Then it's as good as certain!
All right. You and the other support ships will engage the Morganas at close range, and—
*BOOM*
Captain! Are you all right? Captain!
I'll survive! Action stations!
@BATTLE
Easy, Captain. That was a nasty blow you took.
Ugh... feels like my sternum's been sledgehammered.
We were in the wrong place at the wrong time. You took some shrapnel from a hit on my hangar structure.
Then how the hell am I alive?
That armor I sewed into your uniform's thick as anything, Captain. You'll have a bugger of a bruise, but nothing you can't walk off.
I owe you one.
... Out of curiosity, where did you get the metal for that?
Trimmed from the last hit on my hangar structure. Bloody great nuisance, that...
It's from your structure?
Well, I wasn't doing anything with it. I thought you could use a piece of me here and there.
And the Morganas?
Fled into the Red Sea. Shall we pursue, Captain?
I'll notify Command. The East Indies Station have a base in Aden. They'll clean up.
I see.
... We have a lot to talk about, don't we?
Give me a day or so.
One more won't kill us.
I've never seen seven skips before. Excellent throw!
Is this your first time seeing the Red Sea?
I've only ever heard about it. You can see both coasts from here... it's like the gateway to the rest of the Empire, isn't it? The rest of the world...
Command's mulling sending us to India. The Indian Ocean maelstrom's gotten bigger lately.
Another day, Captain. Skip with me?
Oh... I suppose so. Where's this from?
Picked it up in Fair Isle. I've been holding on to it in case we ever left Europe.
Heh, thanks. Between this and sewing, you've got some relaxing hobbies.
It sets my mind at ease, Captain. After all, why do you think your people fight so much?

Fields.MenuText: Who knows?
War is the continuation of diplomacy...
Does it matter?

Fields.DialogueText: I think I can guess.
Impatience. Misunderstandings. Call it what you will.
It does to me, lately.
Every war starts as a misunderstanding, I think. People talk to each other. Then they talk past each other. Then they shoot at each other.
Coleridge said that controversy comes from people interpreting the same thing different ways.
Fair assessment. It's why I want to travel one day. I think the more people visit and learn about each other's homes, the easier it is to understand each other. Hence the rocks.
Foreign rocks in foreign waters?
It's a start. Gives me hope. Helps me think, too.
I hadn't thought of it that way.
No, but you would have.
I would have?
You're in this war for the right reasons, Captain. You want to make it safe for people to talk to each other.
I feel safer already.
Well, that's one mystery solved.
One?
You haven't asked about the flowers.
Right. What were they again?
Yellow acacia and globe amaranth. Seems the Prince of Monaco fancies himself an amateur matchmaker.
Why? What do they mean?
Secret love. Immortal love. Respectively.
By which you mean...?
There's your next mystery, Captain. If ever you need a hint... here I am.
Oh, Captain! Isn't it beautiful out here?
Ooh, five! You're a natural.
Think I've got what it takes?
